objective: To understand the power of words and how they can express thoughts and feelings.
explanation:
• Words are like magic tools that help us communicate thoughts and feelings.
• We use words to ask for things, share stories, and solve problems.
• Kind words can make others feel good and help us build friendships.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Story Time Retell
Materials Needed: A short storybook
Steps to Follow: 1. Read the story aloud. 2. Ask the child to retell the story in their own words.
What Should Be Achieved: Practice storytelling and understanding sequence.
What is Gained: Verbal expression and memory development.
steps: 1. Read the story aloud. 2. Ask the child to retell the story in their own words.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Magic Word Game
Materials Needed: List of kind words (e.g., please, thank you)
Steps to Follow: 1. Say a kind word. 2. Ask the child what it means and when it could be used.
What Should Be Achieved: Understanding of polite language.
What is Gained: Awareness of kindness and appropriate language.
steps: 1. Say a kind word. 2. Ask the child what it means and when it could be used.
gained: Awareness of kindness and appropriate language.

objective: To develop the ability to listen attentively and respond appropriately.
explanation:
• Listening means paying attention when someone else is speaking.
• Good listening helps us understand instructions and stories.
• Listening shows respect and helps us build better friendships.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Whisper Chain
Materials Needed: None
Steps to Follow: 1. Whisper a short sentence to the child. 2. Ask them to repeat it back. 3. Increase sentence complexity gradually.
What Should Be Achieved: Improve focus on words and memory.
What is Gained: Active listening and processing skills.
steps: 1. Whisper a short sentence to the child. 2. Ask them to repeat it back. 3. Increase sentence complexity gradually.
activities.achieved: Improve focus on words and memory.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Sound Hunt
Materials Needed: Audio clips or real-world sounds
Steps to Follow: 1. Play sounds like clapping or animal noises. 2. Ask the child to identify them.
What Should Be Achieved: Listening for understanding.
What is Gained: Sensory engagement and sound recognition.
steps: 1. Play sounds like clapping or animal noises. 2. Ask the child to identify them.

objective: To help children recognize and express their emotions healthily.
explanation:
• Everyone has feelings like happy, sad, angry, or scared.
• Talking about our feelings helps others understand us.
• Naming our emotions helps us feel calm and in control.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Mood Board
Materials Needed: Emotion picture cards
Steps to Follow: 1. Show pictures of faces. 2. Ask child to choose the one matching how they feel.
What Should Be Achieved: Connect facial expressions to emotions.
What is Gained: Self-awareness and emotional vocabulary.
steps: 1. Show pictures of faces. 2. Ask child to choose the one matching how they feel.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Feelings Charades
Materials Needed: Emotion cards
Steps to Follow: 1. Act out an emotion. 2. Let the child guess what it is.
What Should Be Achieved: Practice reading and expressing emotions.
What is Gained: Empathy and expressive communication.
steps: 1. Act out an emotion. 2. Let the child guess what it is.

objective: To understand the importance of non-verbal cues.
explanation:
• We use our face, hands, and body to show how we feel.
• Smiles, frowns, and posture can tell a lot without words.
• Understanding body language helps us know how others feel.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Simon Says (Silent Version)
Materials Needed: None
Steps to Follow: 1. Use only gestures to lead actions (e.g., jump, sit).
What Should Be Achieved: Follow and interpret non-verbal cues.
What is Gained: Non-verbal awareness and body control.
steps: 1. Use only gestures to lead actions (e.g., jump, sit).

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Expression Mirror
Materials Needed: Mirror
Steps to Follow: 1. Make facial expressions. 2. Ask the child to mirror them.
What Should Be Achieved: Recognize emotions through faces.
What is Gained: Empathy and emotional recognition.

objective: To encourage children to ask questions and seek answers.
explanation:
• Questions help us learn new things and understand the world.
• It’s okay to ask “why,” “how,” and “what” questions.
• Being curious makes learning fun and exciting.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Question Walk
Materials Needed: None
Steps to Follow: 1. Walk through a room or outdoor space. 2. Ask the child to ask questions about things they see.
What Should Be Achieved: Spark curiosity and inquiry.
What is Gained: Confidence in asking and exploring.
steps: 1. Walk through a room or outdoor space. 2. Ask the child to ask questions about things they see.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
What’s That Game
Materials Needed: Mystery objects
Steps to Follow: 1. Show objects. 2. Encourage the child to ask what it is or how it works.
What Should Be Achieved: Encourage exploration and vocabulary growth.
What is Gained: Discovery and question-based learning.

objective: To teach children the importance of taking turns and sharing.
explanation:
• Talking and playing nicely means waiting for your turn.
• Everyone gets a chance to speak and play when we take turns.
• Taking turns helps us build patience and fairness.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Turn-Based Game
Materials Needed: Simple board game
Steps to Follow: 1. Take turns playing. 2. Reinforce fair play.
What Should Be Achieved: Practice waiting and sharing.
What is Gained: Patience and social cooperation.
steps: 1. Take turns playing. 2. Reinforce fair play.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Talk and Pass
Materials Needed: Soft toy
Steps to Follow: 1. Pass the toy. 2. Only the holder can speak.
What Should Be Achieved: Practice conversation and turn-taking.
What is Gained: Respectful speaking and listening.
steps: 1. Pass the toy. 2. Only the holder can speak.

objective: To teach children the importance of respecting others.
explanation:
• Respect means being kind and listening to others.
• We show respect by saying “please” and “thank you.”
• Respect helps us make friends and get along with others.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Role Play
Materials Needed: Toy props (optional)
Steps to Follow: 1. Act out respectful situations (sharing, apologizing).
What Should Be Achieved: Understand respectful behavior.
What is Gained: Social development and kindness.
steps: 1. Act out respectful situations (sharing, apologizing).

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Praise Parade
Materials Needed: Toys or group circle
Steps to Follow: 1. Take turns saying something nice to others or toys.
What Should Be Achieved: Practice giving compliments.
What is Gained: Positive peer interactions.

objective: To teach children the power of positive self-talk.
explanation:
• Saying kind things to ourselves helps us feel brave and strong.
• Positive words like “I can do it” encourage us to try.
• Self-talk helps us stay happy even when things are hard.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Affirmation Art
Materials Needed: Paper, crayons
Steps to Follow: 1. Write or draw positive phrases. 2. Decorate and display.
What Should Be Achieved: Promote encouraging internal dialogue.
What is Gained: Confidence and self-expression.
steps: 1. Write or draw positive phrases. 2. Decorate and display.

activities.originalText:

Steps to Follow: 1. Look in mirror. 2. Say kind phrases about self.
What Should Be Achieved: Practice loving language.
What is Gained: Self-esteem and resilience.

objective: To teach children how to communicate effectively.
explanation:
• Good communication means using words clearly.
• Listening and asking questions helps others understand us.
• Talking calmly helps solve problems and avoid confusion.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Story Swap
Materials Needed: Simple storybook
Steps to Follow: 1. Read a story. 2. Ask child to retell or ask questions.
What Should Be Achieved: Develop two-way communication.
What is Gained: Speaking and comprehension skills.
steps: 1. Read a story. 2. Ask child to retell or ask questions.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Picture Talk
Materials Needed: Picture or photo
Steps to Follow: 1. Look at a picture. 2. Ask the child what’s happening and why.
What Should Be Achieved: Describe and explain ideas clearly.
What is Gained: Clarity and expressive language.

objective: To teach children the importance of empathy and kindness.
explanation:
• Empathy means understanding how someone else feels.
• Kindness means helping and caring for others.
• Being kind and empathetic makes everyone feel loved and safe.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Storytime with Feelings
Materials Needed: Storybook with emotional themes
Steps to Follow: 1. Read story. 2. Discuss how characters might feel.
What Should Be Achieved: Recognize and talk about emotions of others.
What is Gained: Emotional intelligence and compassion.
steps: 1. Read story. 2. Discuss how characters might feel.

Materials Needed: Jar, tokens
Steps to Follow: 1. Add token when someone does a kind act. 2. Celebrate kindness together.
What Should Be Achieved: Reinforce good behavior.
What is Gained: Positive reinforcement of empathy and caring.

objective: To help children recognize and use different tones of voice.
explanation:
• Tone changes how a message is received.
• A friendly tone makes people feel good.
• A loud or angry tone might make others feel upset.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Tone Game
Materials Needed: Voice only
Steps to Follow: 1. Say “Let’s go!” in happy, sad, and angry tones. 2. Ask the child to guess the feeling.
What Should Be Achieved: Recognize tone changes.
What is Gained: Emotional perception and vocal awareness.
steps: 1. Say “Let’s go!” in happy, sad, and angry tones. 2. Ask the child to guess the feeling.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Role Play
Materials Needed: None
Steps to Follow: 1. Pretend to be a robot, monster, or teacher. 2. Match tone of voice to the character.
What Should Be Achieved: Explore tone variety.
What is Gained: Creative speaking and expression.

objective: To teach how to give and follow simple instructions clearly.
explanation:
• Directions help us complete tasks.
• Clear words make directions easier to follow.
• Listening carefully helps understand directions.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Simon Says with Two-Step Instructions
Materials Needed: None
Steps to Follow: 1. Add instructions like “Touch your nose, then jump.” 2. Observe if child follows accurately.
What Should Be Achieved: Practice complex listening.
What is Gained: Directional understanding and memory.
steps: 1. Add instructions like “Touch your nose, then jump.” 2. Observe if child follows accurately.

activities.originalText:

Steps to Follow: 1. Give step-by-step drawing instructions (e.g., draw a circle, then a square).
What Should Be Achieved: Follow detailed instructions.
What is Gained: Listening, sequencing, and focus.

originalData.objective: To teach how and why to give genuine apologies.
originalData.explanation:
• Apologies show we care about others' feelings. 
• A sincere apology includes admitting mistakes. 
• Saying “sorry” can help rebuild trust.
originalData.activity1:
Apology Practice
Materials Needed: Role-play slips
Steps to Follow: Act out apology scenarios using empathy and honesty.
What Should Be Achieved: Deliver sincere apologies.
What is Gained: Accountability and empathy.
originalData.activity2:
Fix the Apology
Materials Needed: Examples of weak apologies
Steps to Follow: Read each and rewrite to sound more sincere.
What Should Be Achieved: Understand components of real apologies.
What is Gained: Emotional growth.

objective: To introduce techniques for speaking persuasively and respectfully.
explanation:
• Persuasive speech can influence opinions. 
• Use strong reasons and examples. 
• Stay respectful even when trying to convince someone.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Pitch It!
Materials Needed: Topic ideas, paper
Steps to Follow: Create and deliver a 1-minute persuasive pitch about something you care about.
What Should Be Achieved: Express opinions effectively.
What is Gained: Confidence in argument.
steps: Create and deliver a 1
minute persuasive pitch about something you care about.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Persuasion Planner
Materials Needed: Planning worksheet
Steps to Follow: List reasons and evidence to support your idea.
What Should Be Achieved: Structure a strong argument.
What is Gained: Logical thinking.
steps: List reasons and evidence to support your idea.

objective: To learn how visuals enhance communication.

• Visuals should be clear and helpful. 
• They help explain complex ideas easily.

activities.originalText:
Visual Talk

Steps to Follow: Give a short talk using a visual aid to support your message.
What Should Be Achieved: Enhance speech with visuals.

steps: Give a short talk using a visual aid to support your message.

objective: To practice giving step-by-step instructions others can follow.
explanation:
• Clear instructions avoid confusion. 
• Use sequence words like “first,” “then,” “next.” 
• Check if the other person understood.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Blind Drawing
Materials Needed: Paper, pencil
Steps to Follow: One child gives drawing instructions while the other draws without seeing the image.
What Should Be Achieved: Give effective step-by-step instructions.
What is Gained: Clarity and sequencing.
steps: One child gives drawing instructions while the other draws without seeing the image.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Build It Talk
Materials Needed: Blocks or paper shapes
Steps to Follow: Give verbal instructions for how to build something.
What Should Be Achieved: Deliver organized verbal directions.
What is Gained: Instructional precision.
steps: Give verbal instructions for how to build something.

objective: To learn how to accept constructive criticism without feeling upset.
explanation:
• Feedback helps us grow. 
• Stay calm and listen fully. 
• Ask questions if you don’t understand.

activities.originalText:
Reaction Reflection
Materials Needed: Emotion cards or prompts
Steps to Follow: Discuss how different types of criticism make us feel and why.
What Should Be Achieved: Recognize emotional responses.
What is Gained: Self-awareness.
steps: Discuss how different types of criticism make us feel and why.

activities.originalText:

What Should Be Achieved: Handle criticism positively.
What is Gained: Personal growth mindset.

objective: To teach strategies for resolving disagreements constructively.
explanation:
• Conflicts are normal and can be solved peacefully. 
• Listening and empathy are key to resolving issues. 
• Compromise can help everyone win.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Role-Play Resolution
Materials Needed: Conflict scenario cards
Steps to Follow: Act out a common conflict (e.g., sharing items). Practice solving it calmly.
What Should Be Achieved: Model peaceful conflict resolution.
What is Gained: Better handling of disagreements.
steps: Act out a common conflict (e.g., sharing items). Practice solving it calmly.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Personal Reflection
Materials Needed: Journal or paper
Steps to Follow: Write about a time you solved or witnessed a conflict.
What Should Be Achieved: Reflect on peaceful resolution.
What is Gained: Self-awareness and empathy.
steps: Write about a time you solved or witnessed a conflict.

objective: To develop the skill of convincing others respectfully.
explanation:
• Persuasion involves using facts and emotion. 
• Respect for others’ views is important. 
• A strong voice and structure help influence.

activities.originalText:
Build a Pitch
Materials Needed: Topic ideas, paper
Steps to Follow: Choose a topic (e.g., “Why recess should be longer”) and build a 1-minute argument.
What Should Be Achieved: Structure a clear persuasive argument.
What is Gained: Communication and reasoning skills.

Steps to Follow: Hold a mini-debate with opposing views.
What Should Be Achieved: Practice respectful debate.
What is Gained: Confidence and perspective-taking.

objective: To understand how tone impacts messages.
explanation:
• The way something is said affects how it's received. 
• Tone can change the meaning of words. 
• Being aware of tone helps avoid misunderstandings.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Tone Switch Game
Materials Needed: Common sentences
Steps to Follow: Say the same sentence in happy, sad, angry, and sarcastic tones.
What Should Be Achieved: Hear how tone affects meaning.
What is Gained: Awareness of voice impact.
steps: Say the same sentence in happy, sad, angry, and sarcastic tones.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Story Rewrite
Materials Needed: Short story excerpt
Steps to Follow: Rewrite a scene changing only the tone and mood.
What Should Be Achieved: Understand mood creation through tone.
What is Gained: Emotional nuance in expression.
steps: Rewrite a scene changing only the tone and mood.

objective: To practice participating effectively in group conversations.
explanation:
• Everyone’s voice matters in a discussion. 
• Listening builds group understanding. 
• Staying on topic helps focus.

activities.originalText:
Circle Chat
Materials Needed: Discussion prompts
Steps to Follow: Choose a topic (e.g., “favorite hobby”) and take turns sharing ideas respectfully.
What Should Be Achieved: Practice taking turns and active listening.
What is Gained: Group communication ability.

objective: To understand how to communicate respectfully online.
explanation:
• Online messages lack tone and body language. 
• Kindness and clarity are crucial online. 
• Think before posting or texting.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Emoji Decode
Materials Needed: Printed messages with and without emojis
Steps to Follow: Compare meanings with and without emojis.
What Should Be Achieved: Understand how tone can be altered online.
What is Gained: Digital empathy and clarity.
materials: Printed messages with and without emojis
steps: Compare meanings with and without emojis.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Online Scenario Cards
Materials Needed: Pre-written social media/message examples
Steps to Follow: Discuss what’s respectful and what isn’t.
What Should Be Achieved: Spot online communication issues.
What is Gained: Online safety awareness.
steps: Discuss what’s respectful and what isn’t.

objective: To recognize and appropriately respond to sarcasm.
explanation:
• Sarcasm uses tone to mean the opposite. 
• It can be funny or hurtful depending on use. 
• Understanding context is key.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Sarcasm Sorting
Materials Needed: Sentence cards
Steps to Follow: Read each and decide if it's sarcastic or sincere.
What Should Be Achieved: Identify sarcasm in speech.
What is Gained: Tone comprehension.
steps: Read each and decide if it's sarcastic or sincere.

activities.originalText:

Materials Needed: Sarcastic statements
Steps to Follow: Rewrite them to be sincere and kind.
What Should Be Achieved: Transform negative tone to positive.
What is Gained: Empathy in communication.
steps: Rewrite them to be sincere and kind.

• It's okay to say “no” kindly. 
• Respecting others' boundaries is just as important.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Boundary Circle
Materials Needed: Discussion prompts
Steps to Follow: Talk about different personal boundaries like space, privacy, and sharing.
What Should Be Achieved: Identify personal comfort levels.

Steps to Follow: Practice how to respond when someone crosses a boundary.
What Should Be Achieved: Use kind but firm responses.
What is Gained: Confidence and respect for others.

objective: To understand how body language affects conflict situations.
explanation:
• Body language can escalate or de-escalate conflict. 
 • Facial expressions, posture, and eye contact send strong messages. 
 • Calm gestures show readiness to resolve.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Mirror Practice
Materials Needed: None
Steps to Follow: Pair students and have one show an emotion silently using facial expressions and gestures; the other mirrors it exactly. Rotate emotions like anger, calm, nervous, happy.
What Should Be Achieved: Students become aware of how emotions are communicated nonverbally.
What is Gained: Builds emotional recognition and empathy in conflict situations.
steps: Pair students and have one show an emotion silently using facial expressions and gestures; the other mirrors it exactly. Rotate emotions like anger, calm, nervous, happy.
activities.achieved: Students become aware of how emotions are communicated nonverbally.
gained: Builds emotional recognition and empathy in conflict situations.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Conflict Freeze Frame
Materials Needed: Scripted conflict scenarios
Steps to Follow: Act out a short conflict, freeze at a key moment, and analyze everyone's posture and expressions.
What Should Be Achieved: Students understand how nonverbal cues escalate or de-escalate conflict.
What is Gained: Improves self-regulation and nonverbal awareness.
steps: Act out a short conflict, freeze at a key moment, and analyze everyone's posture and expressions.
activities.achieved: Students understand how nonverbal cues escalate or de-escalate conflict.

objective: To explore how people communicate differently across cultures.
explanation:
• Cultures vary in how they use gestures, tone, and eye contact. 
 • Understanding differences prevents miscommunication. 
 • Respect for all styles is important.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Culture Match-Up
Materials Needed: Flashcards of gestures and matching cultural norms
Steps to Follow: Match each gesture to the culture it's used in. Discuss what it means in that context and whether it means something else elsewhere.
What Should Be Achieved: Recognize cultural variations in nonverbal communication.
What is Gained: Encourages cultural sensitivity and broadens perspective.
materials: Flashcards of gestures and matching cultural norms
steps: Match each gesture to the culture it's used in. Discuss what it means in that context and whether it means something else elsewhere.
activities.achieved: Recognize cultural variations in nonverbal communication.
gained: Encourages cultural sensitivity and broadens perspective.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Role-Switch
Materials Needed: None
Steps to Follow: Role-play greetings or conversations using different cultural communication styles (e.g., bowing, handshakes, direct eye contact).
What Should Be Achieved: Practice adapting communication style respectfully.
What is Gained: Increases global awareness and flexibility in communication.
steps: Role
play greetings or conversations using different cultural communication styles (e.g., bowing, handshakes, direct eye contact).
gained: Increases global awareness and flexibility in communication.

objective: To learn how to say no and stand up for personal values.
explanation:
• Peer pressure can be subtle or direct. 
 • Assertive communication helps resist pressure. 
 • Saying no can be done respectfully.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
No Practice Drill
Materials Needed: Peer pressure scenario cards
Steps to Follow: Read scenarios where someone is pressured. Practice saying “no” assertively using tone, posture, and kind words.
What Should Be Achieved: Develop tools to resist pressure respectfully.
What is Gained: Builds assertiveness and confidence.
steps: Read scenarios where someone is pressured. Practice saying “no” assertively using tone, posture, and kind words.
activities.achieved: Develop tools to resist pressure respectfully.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Story Rewrite
Materials Needed: Short story or comic strip showing someone giving in to pressure
Steps to Follow: Rewrite the ending to show the character standing their ground.
What Should Be Achieved: Explore alternative choices in tough social situations.
What is Gained: Strengthens decision-making and values.

steps: Rewrite the ending to show the character standing their ground.
activities.achieved: Explore alternative choices in tough social situations.

What Should Be Achieved: Explore alternative choices in tough social situations.
What is Gained: Strengthens decision-making and values.

objective: To use emotional awareness in conversations.
explanation:
• Recognizing emotions helps with empathy. 
 • Speaking with emotion can build stronger messages. 
 • Emotional balance supports healthy dialogue.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Emotion Matching
Materials Needed: Phrase cards with various emotional expressions
Steps to Follow: Match each phrase with the emotion it represents. Explain the clues that led to the match.
What Should Be Achieved: Recognize emotional content in speech.
What is Gained: Enhances emotional understanding and expression.
materials: Phrase cards with various emotional expressions
steps: Match each phrase with the emotion it represents. Explain the clues that led to the match.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Talk Back Game
Materials Needed: Emotion cards
Steps to Follow: Say the same sentence using different tones to reflect assigned emotions. Peers guess the emotion.
What Should Be Achieved: Practice using tone to communicate feelings.
What is Gained: Improves emotional expressiveness and empathy.

objective: To learn how to participate effectively in a team.
explanation:
• Every group has different personalities. 
 • Communication roles (leader, mediator, listener) matter. 
 • Respect and cooperation are key.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Role Assignment Game
Materials Needed: Task sheet, role cards (leader, listener, timekeeper, etc.)
Steps to Follow: Assign roles and complete a task (e.g., building a paper tower or planning a party).
What Should Be Achieved: Learn how roles affect group success.
What is Gained: Strengthens collaboration and leadership.
steps: Assign roles and complete a task (e.g., building a paper tower or planning a party).
activities.achieved: Learn how roles affect group success.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Team Reflection
Materials Needed: Reflection worksheet
Steps to Follow: Each member writes what they did, what went well, and what could improve. Share as a group.
What Should Be Achieved: Reflect on group work and roles.
What is Gained: Encourages accountability and team growth.
steps: Each member writes what they did, what went well, and what could improve. Share as a group.
activities.achieved: Reflect on group work and roles.

objective: To spot and respond to manipulative language.
explanation:
• Manipulation uses guilt, pressure, or flattery. 
 • It often benefits one side unfairly. 
 • Calm refusal and questions can stop it.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Spot the Trick
Materials Needed: Statement cards with honest and manipulative phrases
Steps to Follow: Identify which phrases are manipulative and explain why.
What Should Be Achieved: Recognize manipulation tactics.
What is Gained: Builds critical thinking and boundary-setting.
materials: Statement cards with honest and manipulative phrases
steps: Identify which phrases are manipulative and explain why.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Response Builder
Materials Needed: Manipulative phrase cards
Steps to Follow: Practice calm, assertive responses to each phrase.
What Should Be Achieved: Respond effectively without escalating.
What is Gained: Increases confidence and protects personal values.
steps: Practice calm, assertive responses to each phrase.
gained: Increases confidence and protects personal values.

objective: To share ideas without offending others.
explanation:
• Strong opinions can be shared kindly. 
 • Language choice makes a big difference. 
 • Respecting different views builds trust.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Language Tuner
Materials Needed: Opinion statements
Steps to Follow: Rephrase harsh statements to be more respectful while keeping the original point.
What Should Be Achieved: Understand how to soften communication.
What is Gained: Promotes respectful and effective dialogue.
steps: Rephrase harsh statements to be more respectful while keeping the original point.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Group Roundtable
Materials Needed: Discussion topic cards
Steps to Follow: Share opinions in a group, practice listening and disagreeing respectfully.
What Should Be Achieved: Build respectful debate skills.
What is Gained: Improves discussion etiquette and open-mindedness.
steps: Share opinions in a group, practice listening and disagreeing respectfully.

objective: To reflect on how media changes the way we talk and think.
explanation:
• Social media can shape communication habits. 
 • Algorithms can influence what we see and share. 
 • Critical thinking is essential online.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Ad Decoder
Materials Needed: Screenshots or printouts of social media posts
Steps to Follow: Analyze the post’s message, who benefits, and what it makes you feel.
What Should Be Achieved: Think critically about media influence.
What is Gained: Encourages awareness and self-reflection online.
materials: Screenshots or printouts of social media posts
steps: Analyze the post’s message, who benefits, and what it makes you feel.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Reality Check
Materials Needed: Discussion prompts
Steps to Follow: Compare how you speak in texts vs. in-person. Reflect on differences and why they happen.
What Should Be Achieved: Understand online vs. real-world communication.
What is Gained: Increases authenticity and awareness.
steps: Compare how you speak in texts vs. in
person. Reflect on differences and why they happen.

objective: To practice showing appreciation verbally and non-verbally.
explanation:
• Gratitude strengthens relationships. 
 • It can be shown through words, actions, or gestures. 
 • Regular appreciation creates a positive environment.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Gratitude Circle
Materials Needed: None
Steps to Follow: Sit in a circle. Each person says something they appreciate about another.
What Should Be Achieved: Verbalize appreciation sincerely.
What is Gained: Builds connection and positivity.
steps: Sit in a circle. Each person says something they appreciate about another.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Thank You Notes
Materials Needed: Paper, pens
Steps to Follow: Write a short thank-you note to three people. Include something specific.
What Should Be Achieved: Show gratitude in writing.
What is Gained: Develops kindness and written communication.
steps: Write a short thank
you note to three people. Include something specific.

objective: To explore how humor can help or hurt in social situations.
explanation:
• Humor can build connection, relieve tension, or cause harm. 
 • Understanding timing and audience is key. 
 • Not all jokes are kind.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Joke Analyzer
Materials Needed: Joke cards
Steps to Follow: Read jokes and discuss if they are kind, neutral, or hurtful. Explain why.
What Should Be Achieved: Learn the impact of different types of humor.
What is Gained: Builds social awareness and empathy.
steps: Read jokes and discuss if they are kind, neutral, or hurtful. Explain why.
activities.achieved: Learn the impact of different types of humor.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Rewrite Challenge
Materials Needed: Mean-spirited joke examples
Steps to Follow: Rewrite jokes to make them kind and still funny.
What Should Be Achieved: Show that humor can be positive.
What is Gained: Encourages creativity and kindness.
steps: Rewrite jokes to make them kind and still funny.
activities.achieved: Show that humor can be positive.
